text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.
-- The state plans to borrow 600 billion francs in 1997 to finance its debt, including 320 billion francs of OATs, 280 billion francs of BTANs.
-- In New Year's Eve address, President Jacques Chirac defines priorities for 1997, including more jobs for young people and lower taxes.
-- Paris bourse last year registered its best performance since 1989, boosted by highs on Wall Street.
-- Intermarche supermarkets group to seek foreign alliances, international development.

-- France Telecom prepares for end of its French telecommunications monopoly on January 1, 1998. Former telecoms manager Bruno Lasserre says in an interview that he sees no more than three main operators in the French market, with others developing niche services.
-- Members of Airbus consortium to meet on Friday to study change in status to that of a limited company.
-- Air France sets out three-year plan to end of 1999, seeks to improve productivity and client relations, calls for 15 percent cost cuts to catch up with competitors.
-- 62 percent of French people hope progress toward a single currency will continue, and 55 percent think Prime Minister Alain Juppe will lose his job this year, survey shows.
